content.description: A tricky start over a bulge leads to a fun and powerful roof encounter, followed by sequential dynamic climbing that is very continuous with no good rest stances. Stick clip recommended.
content.location: The second route from the left on the Big Deck (see overview photo).
Obvious north facing wall in the middle of Nature Center Wall.

content.description:
The small roof crack on the cover of, and listed as an oddball project in, the Dave Robb guide. It's kind of a weaker, Ogden quartzite version of the Coffin Roof in Little Cottonwood Canyon. Basically, it's a boulder problem 60 feet off of the deck.

This is located on what Robb calls the SR-71 part of the Nature Center Wall.  The roof is not that obvious until you're up close, or just know where to look. But once you are standing at the base of the descent gully which splits the SR-71 wall (and the only really gully to split the whole nature center wall) you can gaze the roof above you on the right wall of the gully.

Pitch 1: Really just a scramble approach. I don't think a rope or climbing shoes are required to get up to the base of the 10 foot dihedral that guards passage to the roof.  ~40 feet. Build a belay with some larger hand sized cams.

Pitch 2: Begin up the 5.9ish (it's been a few years since I climbed it) dihedral.  There will be a small awkward perch at the base of the roof atop this.  Here you can stuff in a few finger sized cams and try (strenuously) to stretch out and gander at the moves.  Step 2 of this: Pull hard some finger locks and edges. After surmounting the roof and making a few easy moves to the top of the wall. Down climb and down aid - No anchor - back to the belay atop pitch 1.
content.protection: For pitch two.  A hand ful of finger sized cams and nuts.  A .75 (green) camalot to place above the roof and whatever cams the dihedral takes. Remember some larger cams up to #3 camalot for the Pitch 1 belay.

content.description: Classic pumpy quartzite. Continuous climbing on mostly large, although smooth, sloping holds.
content.location: The left of the two routes on the Sun Deck wall (see overview photo). Head north from the trailhead on the Bonneville Shoreline Trail and head uphill on talus when you are below the wall.

content.description: The missing bolt mentioned in the old Robb guide has been replaced, and the route has been further cleaned and is now a safe lead. A difficult start under a roof featuring dynamic campus moves leads to gradually easier climbing above. Stick clip recommended.
content.location: The furthest left climb on the Big Deck (see overview photo for location).
The only bolted line on the wall to the left of Long Legged Girls and Fun.

content.description: Average quartzite crack with easy gear placement.
content.protection: Standard rack, maybe less. Shares anchors with Couch Surfing.
content.location: Left of Couch Surfing (the only bolted line on the wall)

content.description: Pumpy quartzite climbing on large sloping holds, similar to Forearm Foreplay but with some better stances and holds.
content.location: The right of the two routes at the Sun Deck (see overview photo). Head north from the trailhead on the Bonneville Shoreline Trail and head uphill on talus when you are below the wall.

content.description: Climbs the bolted line just left of Big Jake. AKA  Puking Pumpkins, crux is sticking the dyno between the 4th and 5th bolts.
content.protection: Bolted sport route comprised of 5 bolts and single bolt anchor. Some of the bolts and clips are less than ideal in their placement, but appear to be of solid placement.
content.location: Located on the Big Jake wall, which is a short, steep wall near the south end of the Nature Center wall. Descent may be realized by down climbing to the South of route top out.

content.description: A crack you barely need to use.
content.protection: Standard rack. Shares anchors with Couch Surfing.

content.description:
The obvious line up this section of the Nature Center Wall, Big Jake climbs the beautiful, overhanging, leftward-angling offset. This climb is not very long - the business being only about 30 feet - but it is consistently powerful and dynamic with one obvious crux. This thing isn't over until it's over, though!  The climbing is as pumpy and sporty as anything I've been on, of similar difficulty, in the Ogden area.

Some of the bolts are fairly reachy so you may want to make sure this is pre-hung.  I doubled up draws on the third bolt. Also the anchor situation is screwy, given that there isn't really an anchor yet.  Basically just clip and lower off the last bolt before the long, low angle slab that leads up to a bolt right below the top.  Don't get duped into going up there and hoping there are anchors (there aren't).
content.protection: 5 bolts to clip on the way. then the 6th bolt is the anchor bolt.  You may want to bring a bail biner or quicklink to leave. (Or better yet, add another bolt and do it proper!)
content.location: About half way between the center of the Nature Wall and the darker color right-margin of the nature center (known as the Brain Area).  It is a very shallow (6") left-facing, left arching dihedral (offset) on over hanging rock.  "Puking Pumpkins" is the bolted route 10 feet to the left.
